variant.question: How is the SHELL model relevant to the work in the cockpit?

options.text: It helps to identify possible sources of error, and to remove possible causes of error in the performance of flying tasks.
The Hardware-Liveware interface addresses the ability of the crew to adapt to the physical environment, such as seating, placing of the aircraft controls, air quality.
The Software-Liveware interface refers to cockpit automation, which can be a source of error where flight crew have insufficient knowledge of computer systems.
The Liveware-Environment interface refers to the aircraft environment, and the crew use standard operating procedures to function there.

variant.question:
An air traffic controller clears the crew of a Boeing 737 aircraft to descend to FL330, thereafter, he instructs the crew of an Airbus A320 to climb to FL320. The Boeing crew correctly reads back and complies with the issued clearance. The Airbus crew incorrectly reads back their climb clearance to FL330 instead of FL320, and the co-pilot programs the FMS for a climb to FL330. After the incorrect readback, the aircraft is handed over to another controller who notes the selected FL but doesn’t realise it is wrong.
With regard to communication, state which kind of error occurred...

options.text: Explicit, which is subject to confirmation bias.
Implicit, which is subject to misunderstandings due to omissions.
Explicit, which is subject to misunderstandings due to omissions.
Implicit, which is subject to confirmation bias.

variant.question: The choice of words and their packaging become more important in the cockpit of an aircraft because:

options.text: Loss of body language
Loss of perception
Loss of hypertext
Loss of situational awareness

variant.question: The percentage of aeroplane accidents caused by human error is approximately

Analyse the following communication exchange between a pilot and an air traffic controller (ATC): 
  
 (1) ATC: EZY8496, climb level 320 
 (2) Pilot: Climbing level 300, EZY8496 
  
 The pilot then inserts level "300" in the FMS. What type of error is being described? Why didn't the controller notice that the readback was not correct?

options.text: Explicit; and the ATC expected the readback to be correct and did not focus on it.
Implicit; and the ATC could interpret the pilot's readback in different ways.
Implicit; due to faulty communication equipment, he could not hear the pilot.
Explicit; and ATC did not understand the message.

variant.question:
Why must flight safety considerations consider the human error mechanism?
1) It is analysis of an incident or accident which will make it possible to identify what error has been committed and by whom. It is the process whereby the perpetrator is made responsible which may lead to elimination of the error.
2) If we have a better understanding of the cognitive error mechanism, it will be possible to adapt procedures, aircraft interfaces, etc.
3) It is error management procedure which enables us to continuously adjust our actions. The better we understand the underlying mechanism of an error, the better will be our means for detecting and adapting future errors.
4) Since error is essentially human, once it has been identified by the use of procedures, a person will be able to anticipate and deal with it automatically in the future.
The correct statement(s) is (are):
Which of the following statements is an example of a countermeasure that may be used by flight crew in order to manage threats, errors, and undesired aircraft states?

options.text: Standard Operating Procedures (SOPs).
Mismanagement of aircraft systems.
Maintaining the aircraft's anti-icing settings OFF during icing conditions.
Complacency.
